title: Can we report for 'Refusing to Communicate' if:
body:
1. We're on an English-speaking server.
2. Someone starts speaking a non-English language.
3. You ask them nicely to please speak English so that we can understand them.
4. They choose not to at the detriment of their team.

Please. This is ridiculous. I don't even know what language they're speaking and they won't even use pings.

replies.body: No, because it is not against the law to speak another language e.g. South Korean - Mandarin - French - Mexican etc. (Just for examples.)
This isn't a discussion of what's legal, it's a discussion of what's considered "refusing to communicate".

There's no use really reporting them, it's just a thing that they have to get used to. If you just use them yourself then at least you know you're doing your part to teach them to start to communicate.

You can report them on the basis that they are Refusing to Communicate because they don't use pings but can't be reported on the basis that they speak a non-English language in the chat. OCE's got multitudes of different cultures and languages and English is the dominant language here in OCE but it isn't as dominant here as it is in NA, which should be the case (personal opinion). 
Multiculturalism ftw. 
If this server was aimed just to accommodate the English dominant countries in this area then it wouldn't be called OCE. It'd be called ANZ server.

> If this server was aimed just to accommodate the English dominant countries in this area then it wouldn't be called OCE. It'd be called ANZ server.

It'd probably just be called the AUS server. I've never heard of a game using "ANZ" for a server. NZ misses out on so much because of us...
I'll accept French and any of the various island nation languages from OCE. But SEA has its own server.

Firstly, the OCE server has no official language. The community generally accepts that it's an "English speaking server" but it officially isn't (I'd like to point out that the OCE region [not referring to the server here] has more than 20 official languages). Secondly, reporting for a language barrier is false reporting, as long as they use pings the way they're meant to be use the person is still communicating.

If they're not using pings though, go ahead.
